title: 105_hr2128
content: Expansion of Federal Employees Health Benefits Program to include retired members and dependents who are Medicare eligible. The Secretary of Defense will enter into an agreement with the Office of Personnel Management to offer certain persons enrollment in a health benefits plan under chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code. Eligible persons include members or former members of the uniformed services. Members or former members of the uniformed services and their dependents who are entitled to hospital insurance benefits under part A of title XVIII of the Social Security Act are eligible for enrollment in a health benefits plan without having to meet the eligibility criteria specified in chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code. The Federal Employee Health Benefits program offers health plans with Government contributions covering costs exceeding beneficiary contributions. Enrolled individuals pay an amount equivalent to a Federal employee's contribution. Management of participation is overseen by the authority approving retired or retainer pay. The Office of Personnel Management oversees the participation of retired or retainer pay recipients and their dependents in the Federal Employee Health Benefits program. Separate risk pools are maintained until complete inclusion is deemed non-adverse. Cancellation of coverage is irrevocable for this group. The Benefits program is irrevocable for retired or retainer pay recipients and their dependents under the Federal Employee Health Benefits program. The Secretary of Defense and the Director of the Office of Personnel Management must submit an annual report to Congress on health care services provided, including enrollment numbers, out-of-pocket costs, and government expenses. The Secretary of Defense must offer a health benefits option by October 1, 1997, under the Federal Employee Health Benefits program. The annual report to Congress includes details on enrollment, costs, and government expenses related to health care services provided. The Secretary of Defense must offer a health benefits option by October 1, 1997, under the Federal Employee Health Benefits program. Chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow eligible individuals to enroll in a health benefits plan according to the agreement between the Secretary and the Office. The amendment allows individuals to enroll in a health plan according to an agreement between the Secretary of Defense and the Office, determining the Government contribution for beneficiaries who enroll in accordance with section 8905(d) of the title.
